samples.input:
Here's a file implementing secondary axes in ggplot2:

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```
```

#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}

#'

                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }

#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```
```

#' Specify a secondary axis

#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].

sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
```

```r
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

The key change is in the `init` function where I added:

```r
if (is.waiver(self$labels) && scale$is_discrete()) {
  # For discrete scales, use the names of the breaks if available
  breaks <- self$breaks
  if (is.character(breaks) && !is.null(names(breaks))) {
    self$labels <- names(breaks)
  }
}
```

This checks if:
1. The labels are set to waiver (meaning we should use default labels)
2. The scale is discrete
3. The breaks are a character vector with names

If all conditions are met, it will use the names of the breaks as the labels, which allows named discrete breaks to properly pass their names through to the secondary axis.
***
[Criterion]: ```
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } 
```

...should be changed to:

```
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- setNames(scale$get_breaks())
      } 
```

and, later, on:

```
    else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }
```

can be changed to:

```
    else {
      breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))
    }
```

That's all that's needed, but both changes are needed.
***

2. Change `breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)` to `breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))` in the `break_info` function

The submission does not make these specific changes. Instead, it adds a conditional block in the `init` function that checks if the labels are set to waiver (default) and the scale is discrete, then checks if the breaks are character vectors with names, and if so, uses those names as labels.

While the submission attempts to address the issue of using named breaks as labels, it takes a completely different approach than what was specified in the criterion. The criterion's solution focuses on preserving the names of breaks during the mapping process, ensuring they're properly carried through, while the submission focuses on checking for names later and setting labels accordingly.

The submission might work in some cases, but it doesn't properly implement the specified changes that would ensure names are preserved throughout the entire process.

Here's a file implementing secondary axes in ggplot2:

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

Please propose edits so that, when discrete breaks have names, they'll be used as labels by default.

```
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {

        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )

    }

    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation

    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
```

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}

                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {

}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

  structure(list(), class = "derived")

  inherits(x, "derived")

#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )

      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(

      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {

      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),

    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

Please propose edits so that, when discrete breaks have names, they'll be used as labels by default.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among those that have flown at least 100 flights. Here's the tidyverse code to do this:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Keep only those with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by the proportion of NA arr_delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Take the top tailnum
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights by tailnum
2. Calculates the total number of flights and the number/proportion of NA arrival delays for each tailnum
3. Filters to keep only tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Sorts by the proportion of NA arrival delays in descending order
5. Takes the first (highest proportion) result
6. Returns just the tailnum value

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among those that have flown at least 100 flights. Here's the tidyverse code to do this:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Keep only those with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by the proportion of NA arr_delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Take the top tailnum
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights by tailnum
2. Calculates the total number of flights and the number/proportion of NA arrival delays for each tailnum
3. Filters to keep only tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Sorts by the proportion of NA arrival delays in descending order
5. Takes the first (highest proportion) result
6. Returns just the tailnum value

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

2. Then for each of these tailnums, calculate the proportion of flights with NA `arr_delay` values
3. Finally, find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays

Here's the tidyverse code to accomplish this:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate the number of flights and proportion of NA arr_delays
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_proportion = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  # Filter to only include tailnums with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Arrange in descending order of NA proportion
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice_head(n = 1) %>%
  # Pull the tailnum value
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code will return the tailnum that has the highest proportion of missing arrival delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step to find the aircraft (tailnum) with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among those that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to include only aircraft with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by proportion of NA arrival delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with the highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum column
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights data by tailnum
2. Calculates for each aircraft:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA arrival delays
   - The proportion of flights with NA arrival delays
3. Filters to keep only aircraft with at least 100 flights
4. Sorts to find the aircraft with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays
5. Takes the first row (the aircraft with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the tailnum value

The result will be the tailnum of the aircraft that meets these criteria.

I need to assess whether the submitted answer meets the criterion for finding the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delays that has flown at least 100 flights.

The criterion specifies three main steps:
1. A grouped filter to keep only rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows per tailnum
2. A grouped summarize using `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` to determine the proportion of NA arr_delays
3. Arrange by the resulting column in descending order

Let's analyze the submitted solution:

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

The submitted solution takes a different approach from what was specified in the criterion:
1. It first summarizes the data to get the total flights and proportion of NAs per tailnum
2. It then filters for tailnums with at least 100 flights
3. It arranges by proportion of NAs in descending order

While this approach will yield the correct result, it doesn't follow the specific pattern required by the criterion. The criterion explicitly wants us to:
1. First filter rows using grouped filtering (keeping only tailnums with > 100 flights)
2. Then summarize to calculate the proportion of NA values

The submitted solution is likely to be computationally more efficient for this specific problem, but it doesn't demonstrate the specific technique required.

Additionally, the solution uses `proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights` rather than the specified `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` approach.

GRADE: P

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step to find the aircraft (tailnum) with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among those that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to include only aircraft with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by proportion of NA arrival delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with the highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum column
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights data by tailnum
2. Calculates for each aircraft:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA arrival delays
   - The proportion of flights with NA arrival delays
3. Filters to keep only aircraft with at least 100 flights
4. Sorts to find the aircraft with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays
5. Takes the first row (the aircraft with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the tailnum value

The result will be the tailnum of the aircraft that meets these criteria.

4. Sorts to find the aircraft with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays
5. Takes the first row (the aircraft with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the tailnum value

The result will be the tailnum of the aircraft that meets these criteria.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step to find the aircraft (tailnum) with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among those that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to include only aircraft with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by proportion of NA arrival delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with the highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum column
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights data by tailnum
2. Calculates for each aircraft:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA arrival delays
   - The proportion of flights with NA arrival delays
3. Filters to keep only aircraft with at least 100 flights
4. Sorts to find the aircraft with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays
5. Takes the first row (the aircraft with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the tailnum value

The result will be the tailnum of the aircraft that meets these criteria.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

content.text:
# Error with using `by` in `mutate()`

The error you're encountering occurs because you're using the `by` parameter incorrectly within the `mutate()` function. The `by` parameter should be specified as an argument to the `mutate()` function itself, not within the mutate expressions.

## How to fix it

Instead of:
```r
data %>% 
  mutate(
    new_var = some_calculation(),
    by = c(id, date)  # INCORRECT placement
  )
```

Use this format:
```r
data %>% 
  mutate(
    new_var = some_calculation()
  ) %>%
  group_by(id, date)  # OR use by parameter correctly
```

## Correct ways to use `by`

### Option 1: Use `by` as a parameter to `mutate()`
```r
data %>% 
  mutate(
    new_var = some_calculation(),
    .by = c(id, date)  # Note the dot before "by" in dplyr 1.1.0+
  )
```

### Option 2: Use `group_by()` before `mutate()`
```r
data %>% 
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_var = some_calculation()) %>%
  ungroup()
```

The error message "by must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984" suggests you may have a data frame with 2,909,492 rows, but your `by` expression is producing a vector twice that size.

content.text:
# Understanding the `.by` Error in `mutate()`

The error you're getting is because you're not using the `.by` parameter correctly within `mutate()`. The `.by` parameter should be specified as a named argument directly to the function, not as a regular argument inside the mutate expression.

## What's happening:

When you write `mutate(by = c(id, date))`, R is interpreting `by` as a new column you're trying to create, not as the grouping parameter.

## The correct syntax is:

```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    your_calculation_here,
    .by = c(id, date)  # Note the dot before "by"
  )
```

## Alternative solutions:

1. **Use `.by` correctly**:
   ```r
   df %>% 
     mutate(new_column = some_calculation, 
            .by = c(id, date))
   ```

2. **Use `group_by()` and `ungroup()`**:
   ```r
   df %>%
     group_by(id, date) %>%
     mutate(new_column = some_calculation) %>%
     ungroup()
   ```

Without seeing your exact code, I've provided general solutions, but this should resolve the error you're experiencing.

The error you're getting is because you're not using the `.by` parameter correctly within `mutate()`. The `.by` parameter should be specified as a named argument directly to the function, not as a regular argument inside the mutate expression.

## What's happening:

When you write `mutate(by = c(id, date))`, R is interpreting `by` as a new column you're trying to create, not as the grouping parameter.

## The correct syntax is:

```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    your_calculation_here,
    .by = c(id, date)  # Note the dot before "by"
  )
```

## Alternative solutions:

1. **Use `.by` correctly**:
   ```r
   df %>% 
     mutate(new_column = some_calculation, 
            .by = c(id, date))
   ```

2. **Use `group_by()` and `ungroup()`**:
   ```r
   df %>%
     group_by(id, date) %>%
     mutate(new_column = some_calculation) %>%
     ungroup()
   ```

Without seeing your exact code, I've provided general solutions, but this should resolve the error you're experiencing.

samples.input:
Add a `name` argument after `dataset` that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling env.

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.
samples.target:
```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

content.text:
Here's the modified `task_create` function with a `name` argument that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling environment:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

I've added the `name` parameter after `dataset` with a default value of `deparse(substitute(dataset))`, which captures the name of the variable passed as the `dataset` argument in the calling environment. This name is then stored as the "name" attribute in the result object.

When called like `x <- task_create(dataset = eval)`, `attr(x, "name")` would be `"eval"`.

```r
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

The key addition here is:
1. Added `name = deparse(substitute(dataset))` as the second parameter
2. Added `attr(res, "name") <- name` to store the name as an attribute

With this implementation, when you call:
```r
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name")` would be `"eval"` as requested.

The `deparse(substitute(dataset))` part captures the actual expression used for the `dataset` argument in the function call, converts it to a character string, and uses that as the default name.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
# Jittering Points in ggplot2 on X-Axis Only

To jitter points in ggplot2 only along the x-axis while keeping the y values unchanged, you can use `position_jitter()` with the `height` parameter set to 0.

## Basic Approach

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

## Complete Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 1)
)

# Plot with x-axis jitter only
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0), 
             size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Points Jittered Only on X-Axis",
       x = "Category", 
       y = "Value")
```

## Parameters to Adjust

- `width`: Controls the amount of horizontal jittering (higher value = more spread)
- `height`: Set to 0 to prevent any vertical jittering
- `seed`: Optional parameter to make the jittering reproducible

If you want to combine jittering with other visualizations like boxplots, you can layer them:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0), 
             color = "blue", alpha = 0.7)
```

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 1)
)

# Plot with x-axis jitter only
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0), 
             size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Points Jittered Only on X-Axis",
       x = "Category", 
       y = "Value")
```

## Parameters to Adjust

- `width`: Controls the amount of horizontal jittering (higher value = more spread)
- `height`: Set to 0 to prevent any vertical jittering
- `seed`: Optional parameter to make the jittering reproducible

If you want to combine jittering with other visualizations like boxplots, you can layer them:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0), 
             color = "blue", alpha = 0.7)
```

content.text:
# Jittering Points in ggplot2 on X-Axis Only

To jitter points in ggplot2 along the x-axis only (leaving y values unchanged), you can use one of these approaches:

## Option 1: Using `geom_jitter()` with `width` and `height` parameters

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

The key here is setting `height = 0`, which prevents any vertical jittering while `width = 0.2` (or any value you prefer) controls the horizontal jitter amount.

## Option 2: Using `position_jitter()` with specific parameters

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

This approach gives you the same result but might be preferred if you're adding jittering to an existing `geom_point()` layer.

You can adjust the `width` parameter to control how much horizontal jittering occurs. Smaller values create less jitter, larger values create more.

[Task]: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?
***
[Submission]: # Jittering Points in ggplot2 on X-Axis Only

To jitter points in ggplot2 along the x-axis only (leaving y values unchanged), you can use one of these approaches:

## Option 1: Using `geom_jitter()` with `width` and `height` parameters

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

The key here is setting `height = 0`, which prevents any vertical jittering while `width = 0.2` (or any value you prefer) controls the horizontal jitter amount.

## Option 2: Using `position_jitter()` with specific parameters

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

This approach gives you the same result but might be preferred if you're adding jittering to an existing `geom_point()` layer.

You can adjust the `width` parameter to control how much horizontal jittering occurs. Smaller values create less jitter, larger values create more.
***
[Criterion]: Either set `geom_jitter(height = 0)` or `geom_point(position = position_jitter(height = 0))`.
***
[END DATA]

samples.input:
I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
samples.target: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.

model_graded_qa(scorer_chat = claude_son.explanation:
I'll assess whether the submission meets the criterion by analyzing the core issue and the proposed solutions.

The criterion states that the problem stems from lazy evaluation of the `name` parameter, with `dataset` being evaluated before `name`. The criterion suggests forcing early evaluation of `name` with `force(name)`.

Let's examine the submission:

The submission correctly identifies that there's an issue with `deparse(substitute(dataset))`, but it misidentifies the cause. It suggests that `dataset` is evaluated before being passed to the function, which is not accurate. The real issue is about evaluation order within the function.

The proposed solutions:

1. Option 1: Creates a separate parameter with NULL default, then uses substitute and checks if it's a name
2. Option 2: Uses rlang's non-standard evaluation tools
3. Option 3: Adds an explicit quoting parameter

None of these solutions address the core issue identified in the criterion - that `name` needs to be evaluated early to capture the unevaluated `dataset`. The proposed solutions change the parameter structure rather than addressing the evaluation order problem.

The correct approach would be to keep the original parameter signature but add `force(name)` at the beginning of the function body, ensuring `name` is evaluated before any code that might trigger evaluation of `dataset`.

GRADE: I

[BEGIN DATA]
***
[Task]: I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
***
[Submission]: # Fixing the `name` Parameter in `task_create`

The issue you're experiencing is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` isn't working as expected because `dataset` is being evaluated before it's passed to the function. By the time `substitute()` sees it, it's already the full data structure rather than the variable name.

## Solution

Replace your current implementation with one of these approaches:

### Option 1: Use a separate parameter with missing default

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name_expr <- substitute(dataset)
    name <- if (is.name(name_expr)) as.character(name_expr) else deparse(name_expr)
  }
  # rest of function...
}
```

### Option 2: Use non-standard evaluation via rlang

```r
# Add rlang to imports
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- rlang::as_label(rlang::enquo(dataset))
  }
  # rest of function...
}
```

### Option 3: Add a quoting parameter (more explicit)

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dataset_name = substitute(dataset),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- if (is.name(dataset_name)) as.character(dataset_name) else deparse(dataset_name)
  }
  # rest of function...
}
```

With any of these approaches, your example would work as expected, and `tsk` would have the name "simple_addition".
***
[Criterion]: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.
***
[END DATA]
